comments.commentBody:
@jkb: There may not BE another outlet for his abilities. Swimmers at the upper echelons are pretty monomaniacal, and Phelps, his mother, and his coach pursued it to the n-th degree. Problem is, there never was any second act envisioned, leaving him to retire and unretired like some latter day athletic Sarah Bernhardt.
Phelps' mother garnered a lot of praise for keeping him on track to become the Olympian with the most medals, and much was made of her career in education. but there appears to have been no preparation for what comes after. I know that he is now an adult, but he needed wise counsel now more than he ever did, and it appears that his coach is completely incapable of offering that, and, sadly, his mother hasn't been able to do so ether.
My kids both swam and neither was ever an elite swimmer, but they had close friends and teammates who were. One thing for sure, swimmers do like party. My kids were about the straightest arrows in the quiver in any team they were ever on (summer rec league, CYO, year round club swimming, high school, and, for one of them, D-III college swimming).
And check out AA.
You can not blame the patents for everything. He should check out the Twelve Steps.

Agree.  Mets and Jets are textbook examples of owners in over their heads.  For excellence think Patriots and Red Sox.  Both are smart enough to hire top tier management and leave them alone to do their job.

Ryan started as head coach with Eric Mangini's team. The Jets have gone steadily downhill from there as every year Ryan's awful picks took over more and more of the roster spots that Mangini's players had been in.

Rex Ryan has been an absolute disaster for the N.Y. Jets. This current mess is his creation, with a big assist from an incompetent, silver-spoon owner and his equally inept GM's.

Anything Rex does to compare himself to Belichik invites ridicule.

"On to {whoever kills us next}". eh Rex?

That's a silly post "Numbers23". How do you define winning? Championships? Playoffs? Competitiveness? How much do you know about the Royals, and how the 2013 season set them up for success in 2014? Are you saying that a Wild Card entry makes a team a less legitimate champion? I guess the Packers 2010 [season] Super Bowl victory would be negated by your criteria. The Jets DID have success, by most people's standards, in 2009 and 2010. In 2011 they were competitive until Week 16, against the Giants, and then the wheels started falling off over the next few seasons. In the egalitarian NFL, too, there really is no such thing as "big market" or "small market" when it comes to determining success. Every NFL team, theoretically, has a chance to succeed if they have a franchise QB, draft well and make the proper free agent acquisitions. Recent Super Bowl winners Green Bay, Seattle and New Orleans are not big market cities by anyone's definition.  You are unwittingly right in one sense, though for the wrong reason. The Jets being $20+ million under the salary cap, with all their glaring deficiencies, essentially makes them the equivalent of a small market franchise by *choice.* That is likely a scenario that will not be repeated next year.

Look at the difference in the press conferences of Ryan and Coughlin after losses. It tells you all you need to know: One, Ryan, looks clueless, demoralized.
comical and sad. Look at the other, he's angry, determined, demanding, fiery
and intelligent.
Much as I liked REx and hated Coughlin at first, my opinion has changed drastically. Rex looks like a sad confused clown. Bye bye, the circus is closing.

" Grave legal consequences for false allegations make it unlikely for accuser to come forward otherwise."

Does Twana Brawley ring a bell?
Anywhere from 2-8% of rape allegations are false [Wikipedia]. "A false accusation may be perpetrated out of a desire for attention or sympathy, anger or revenge, or to cover up behavior deemed "inappropriate" by their condemning surrounding culture. Statements by the Finnish Police estimate that false rape accusations have risen in like manner with female alcohol consumption in the country and that many false rape accusations are made when intoxicated. Many of the people falsely accused of rape are men of immigrant background."
[Wikipedia].
Recall the Duke Lacrosse accusations that were ultimately proved false? The accuser suffered no grave legal consequences at all, except that later she was found guilty of murder in an unrelated case.

I think you have to reconsider your statement.
Really?  Sounds more like it's sexually motivated.
Oh my.  Well,  this physician (married to his same-gender partner of 31 years) thinks you might want to consider switching to decaf.

"Grave legal consequences for false allegations make it unlikely for accuser to come forward otherwise."

Not so. Not so at all.

Unless we want a Constitution covered with Post-It notes, the SCOTUS isn't (shouldn't act like) a judicial eight-ball that simply bends to political fashion, nor can they direct the lower court(s) on how to rule in important cases that could come to them.
They may choose (or have no option but) to let the issue(s) percolate at the State / Appellate level until it produces a petition that is actually relevant to interpretation under Constitutional law.

I find it very disturbing The New York Times would support this guilty until proven innocent philosophy. Particularly in cases where the alleged assailants are men of color who so often have been unfairly victimized and imprisoned by a criminal justice system that discriminates against them.

Continuing to call the investigations into Mr. Winston's case "deeply flawed" does not make that lie any more true. A lie spouted by the accusers aunt/attorney who desperately is trying to get a large sum of money from Mr. Winston and attempted to extort $7 million dollars from him.

Anyone who supports the suspension given to Mr. Harris, I accuse you of murder. A very serious charge. I fully expect you to notify your employer of this tomorrow and ask to be indefinitely suspended from work until you can clear your name. I know I have your full support on this matter and our agreed upon course of action and the full support of The New York Times.
This PC rush-to-justice is disturbingly similar to Deep South lynchings not that long ago.  All it took was a white woman claiming a black man acted inappropriately.

The difference is that cats and horses don't receive employee benefits. Nor are they capable of making a conscious lifetime commitment or entering a contract. Nor are they able to co-parent a minor child. As for brothers and sisters, the taboo against sibling marriage is practical for medical reasons.

Then lets see the evidence. I would think the fact that the police have not made an arrest proves that they don't have this evidence at this time. Even then he may not be guilty.
The point is that the university has jumped way out in front of this due to PC pressure. They had better hope that he isn't innocent because I think Duke University paid out a huge settlement when they got a little too aggressive in their assumption of guilt even after charges were filed.

Yes and I would think that his own attorney, who should know a little more about the situation than you, I, and many other others making comments has this to say:

"Harris has not been arrested, his lawyer, Huntley Johnson, said.

“We are cooperating with the investigation, and I’m hopeful that there will not be an arrest in this case,” Johnson said by phone Monday."

Johnson added that he thought the suspension from team activities was fair.

“The university has their rules, and based on what they know at this point, it’s appropriate,” he said. “In the long run, I hope it’s not appropriate.”

Settle down and wait for that information to trickle down to your station in life before making accusations of jumping "way out in front of this due to PC pressure."

He may not have been suspended for the accusation of rape, the story says he was suspended for breaking the university's rules, whatever that means.
like at Fla. St., with Winston?

Many of the commenters here are critical of the decision to suspend before justice has taken its course. My first thought, however, was that perhaps there is such strong evidence that the President of U of F would be criticized for not immediately taking action once the full story comes out. In other words, once we know more, perhaps this immediate suspension will make sense.
Wrong.  Increasing numbers of Americans are just fine with same sex marriage, the number of those who disapprove is shrinking.

Laws in the united states are not based purely on morality. They have to be based on harm. Enacting a discriminatory law that targets something that does no harm is never going to be constitutional. Jews and Muslims consider eating pork to be grievously immoral, but they don't try to enact laws to prevent other people from eating it. Christians consider working on Sundays to be grievously immoral, but they don't (at least not anymore) pass laws to prevent other people from working on Sundays. Murder, rape, theft, these things have demonstrable harms. You don't even have to get into morality to justify laws against them. Gay marriage? Not so much.
Morality is a subjective thing.

Society as a whole decides what is morally wrong and what is morally acceptable and the majority of society believes that gay marriage is wrong and should not be allowed. The courts have overstepped their positions and duties. We must not allow the courts to trample on the beliefs of the people! We must fight back against this wrong doing!
Well said!
No. No. nope. Ask Utah if  the Supreme Court left it up to the states. The supremes left it up to the Courts in each judicial circuit to rule. When there is a disagreement they will likely rule.
Looks like the Supreme Court is leaving it up to the States.  Fair enough.

Anybody here ever heard of Miroto Dance Theater? South Java; discovered them last month. Flat-out astounded; a reality check, please.

Thanks! Please reply.

The last paragraph is so revealing; really there is not reason to read all the rest. You deceive by being long winded!
"Decently" - define that word and let us see the self-righteousness lurking there.

“I think suspending him from athletic activities makes a statement to the larger community that sexual assault is not tolerated and there will be serious consequences,” said Jessie Lazarchik, the community education project coordinator at the Alachua County Victim Services and Rape Crisis Center, near Florida’s campus in Gainesville."

The only problem with the above quote taken from the article is that we don't know if it is true but this person is applauding the punishment of the accused player.
How does she know it is true and how does she justify punishing someone before the incident has been investigated?
Since Jessie Lazarchik contends that suspending the student sends a message that sexual assault will not be tolerated she has obviously already conducted an investigation, weighed the evidence and judged him guilty.
The only message here is that a university is going to punish a student before and regardless of his guilt or innocence to please a special interest group and Jessie Lazarchik.
That is a disturbing message that flies in the face of due process and smacks of mob justice.
Who says marriage creates happiness?  Quite the opposite for a lot of folks I know.
So now we dispense mob justice to anybody accused of rape without an investigation. Tawana Brawley must be asking where you were when her rapist got off.
